text:
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1923, No. 1: This festival, portrayed in this and subsequent views, is not the regular feast of St. Anthony of Padua, which according to the church calendar, should occur on June 13. This has its origin in an early September festival brought over to this country by immigrants from Brusciano, a suburb of Naples. The Bruscianese settled on the east side of First Avenue, and evidently found Labor Day weekend a convenient time for their annual festival. On Saturday they prepare the tall tower, and also parade their statue of St. Anthony around the upper east side Italian section. Then on Monday (Labor Day) the tower is carried back and forth on 106th Street; and an enormous crowd turns out for it. This festival in 1923 is the fifth annual Festa dei Bruscianesi (Festival of the Bruscianese). It will be held here every year until 1932, when the children will have a little Festa of their own, financial stringency inhibiting their elders. There will be one more Festa in 1934, but not in 1935; the opinion of the neighborhood in 1935 seems to be that it will not be continued as a regular annual affair. The first picture shows the boat (evidently part of the saint's legend), which is carried in the procession. St. Anthony stands in the center; and the mast is surmounted by an eagle. Notice the fine figurehead, representing a two-tailed mermaid. The view is east on 106th Street, east of First Avenue. See No. 8. September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 2. The boat, during the noon hour pause of the procession.
September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 3. Offering at a shrine of St. Anthony - a little floral boat.
September 2, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1923, No. 4. Procession, carrying the tall tower, opposite 336 East 106th Street, south side, between First and Second Avenues. The building on the extreme left is the Italian Presbyterian Church of the Ascension, and the five-story apartment house adjoining it is 338 East 106th Street.

September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 5. Another view of the above, showing the boat just ahead of the tower.

September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 6. Another view, showing the street west to Second Avenue. The boat is already moving ahead; and the men around the tower are raising it.

September 3, 1923.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

text:
(1) Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1923, No. 7. Spectators on the balconies, 106th Street, north side, east of First Avenue, watching the procession. September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) No. 8. The tower, a colossal monument, probably of papier mâché, on a wooden skeleton. It is carried in the procession. Surmounting the whole is a statue of St. Anthony. The tower is here pictured on 106th Street, just east of First Avenue, the day before the procession. To the right may be seen the boat, in the position in which it was pictured in No. 1. September 2, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) No. 9. Detail of the tower, taken during the procession. The face shown pictures St. Anthony saving his father from death. The scene of this view is a side street just west of First Avenue. September 3, 1923.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1924, No. 1. The tower at the start of the procession, 106th Street, east of First Avenue. This year the figure surmounting it is an allegorical representation of Peace, bearing a lily in her right hand. The six-story tenement house behind and to the right of the statue is 402 East 106th Street, on the south side. This year the feast was held on Labor Day.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 2. A closer view of the front of the tower as it is borne west across First Avenue by the procession. The view is southeast.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 3. The tower being carried by the procession, which is moving west on 106th Street just after crossing First Avenue. This is a fairly close view of the right side of the statue.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1924, No. 7. A statuette of St. Anthony, conventionalized as usual in Franciscan habit and with a Child on his right arm, flanked by statuettes of Columbia and Italia.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 8. Outdoor shrine of St. Anthony, showing offerings of paper money pinned to the statue of the saint and to that of the Child on his arm.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 9. The same, another view. The place is First Avenue and 106th Street.
September 1, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua, No. 7-9.

text:
(1) Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1925, No. 1. The tower, at rest in 106th Street east of First Avenue, Saturday of Labor Day week-end. A new tower is built for this feast each September. This year the tower is surmounted by a statue of St. Michael treading on the Devil. September 5, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) No. 2. Rear view of the tower, in the final stages of construction; it is standing on 106th Street at First Avenue, facing west. The rear of the tower will be covered with paper flowers. September 5, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) No. 3. A life-size statue of St. Anthony, with offerings of dollar bills pinned to his robe and to the Child's clothes. This is the statue pictured in 1924, 1927, and 1930. In this view it is standing in front of 323-325 East 106th Street. The parading of this statue through the streets is the annual feature of Saturday's festivities. September 5, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1926, No. 1. The tower, surrounded by the crowd, in 106th Street east of First Avenue.
This year the feast was held on Labor Day.
September 6, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. Balloon vendor in 106th Street at First Avenue, the
tower is seen in the background.
September 6, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 1. The tower, at rest in 106th Street, east of First Avenue. The feast this year, the ninth annual feast, was held on Labor Day.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. The tower, in procession, 106th Street east of First Avenue.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 3. The same; the tower is moving west on 106th Street towards Second Avenue.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 4. A close view of the front of the tower as it is carried across First Avenue. Notice the number of men it takes to support it. Musicians are seated at the base of the tower in front of the statue of St. Anthony.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 5. Shrine to St. Anthony on First Avenue near 106th Street. Candles burn before the statue, and two votive images of wax, representing legs, are hung, one on either side of the statue. A small floral boat, flying the American and the Italian flags, may be seen on the right; and the usual offerings of paper money are pinned to St. Anthony's robe.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 4. A close view of the front of the tower as it is carried across First Avenue. Notice the number of men it takes to support it. Musicians are seated at the base of the tower in front of the statue of St. Anthony.

(2)
No. 5. Shrine to St. Anthony on First Avenue near 106th Street. Candles burn before the statue, and two votive images of wax, representing legs, are hung, one on either side of the statue. A small floral boat, flying the American and the Italian flags, may be seen on the right; and the usual offerings of paper money are pinned to St. Anthony's robe.
September 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1928, No. 4. The tower, being carried in the procession on 106th Street, moving west towards First Avenue. It takes three to four dozen men to carry it. a severe eight piece band is riding in front, under the statue of St. Anthony. The boys who manage the ropes also ride on the tower.
Only the two lower sections of the tower are shown. A bishop, with mitre and crozier, occupies the face of the tower in the section above St. Anthony.
September 3, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 5. The same, a closer view, taken as the statue arrives alongside 401 East 106th Street, adjoining the corner of First Avenue.
The camera is close enough to show how the weight of the tower is distributed onto the shoulders of the bearers. Notice also the man in shirt sleeves and straw hat, riding in front among the musicians; he is evidently rendering or leading a song.
September 3, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 6. A close rear view of the tower, which is in about the same position as in view No. 5, but has been turned to face north. The bearers are resting, leaning on the heavy cross-poles by which they lift the whole structure.
September 3, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1928, No. 7. The tower in pro-cession, headed east on 106th Street just west of First Avenue, and almost surrounded by a dense crowd of spectators.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 8. Another view of the same crowd of spectators. The view is north on First Avenue, from and including the N.E. corner of 106th Street.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 9. Sunday scene on the south side of 106th Street, just west of First Avenue, the day before the festival. A woman with watermelons for sale is sitting on an orange crate reading the comics.
The church a few doors down is the Italian Presbyterian Church of the Ascension.
September 2, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1) Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1929, No. 4. The tower, without its surmounting figure, ready to start west on 106th Street. September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) No. 5. The tower in procession, in the middle of the block pictured in No. 4. September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) No. 6. The tower in procession, on 106th Street just west of First Avenue. September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1929, No. 7. The tower, in procession, on 106th Street just west of First Avenue. This view is almost identical with No. 6.
September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 8. A close-up of the men lifting the tower.
September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

No. 9. Men carrying the figure of Mary of the Immaculate Conception, the head-piece of the tower, in preparation for replacing it.
September 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1930, No. 5. The tower at rest in 106th Street, the Saturday of Labor Day week-end. August 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 6. Detail of the front of the tower, where St. Anthony, as usual, occupies the position of honor. Notice the sphinx on either side of him. This view was taken during the procession on Labor Day.
September 1, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 7. Detail of the front and right side of the tower, and the men carrying it.
September 1, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: 1st Avenue Between 105th and 106th Streets, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1931, No. 1. The tower in procession, First Avenue between 106th and 105th Streets; the view is south.

September 7, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. A similar scene, looking south on First Avenue from 106th Street. This year the festival was particularly gorgeous and well-attended.

September 7, 1931.

Nog. # 4969

(3)
No. 3. Rear view of the tower, looking west on 106th Street from First Avenue. The entire block is literally jammed with spectators.

September 7, 1931.

P.L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
(1) Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1932 (Children's Feast): No. 2. The children carrying their tower across First Avenue at 106th Street. September 5, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) No. 3. Another view of the children and their tower, at the N.E. corner of 106th Street; the houses on the west side of the avenue are shown in the background. September 5, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) No. 4. Candy throwing, at the S.E. corner of 106th Street and First Avenue. September 5, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
